abstract.t: In Situ Operations, Administration and Maintenance (IOAM) is used for monitoring network performance and for detecting bottlenecks and anomalies by incorporating IOAM information into in-flight data packets. This document introduces the concept of use case driven IOAM profiles. An IOAM profile defines a use case or a set of use cases for IOAM, and a set of rules that restrict the scope and features of the IOAM specification to a subset of the full functionality.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: IOAM is used for monitoring traffic in the network by incorporating IOAM information into data packets.

This document introduces the concept of use case driven IOAM profiles. An IOAM profile defines a use case or a set of use cases for IOAM, and a set of rules that restrict the scope and features of the IOAM specification to a subset of the full functionality. Based on the guidelines in this document, it is expected that future documents may define one or more IOAM profiles. The current document does not specify any IOAM profiles.

The motivation for defining profiles is to limit the scope of IOAM features, allowing simpler implementation, verification, and interoperability testing in the context of specific use cases that do not require the full functionality of IOAM.

This document does not require any changes in IOAM . Furthermore, it is expected that future IOAM profile specifications will not require changes in IOAM, since a profile, by definition, derives a subset of the existing functionality.

section.title: Overview
section.t: A profile defines a set of rules that limit the scope or functionality of IOAM. By default, any detail in IOAM that is not specifically addressed or limited by the profile is as defined in IOAM . The rest of this section presents a set of topics that may be addressed in a profile specification. A profile may include some or all of these topics, and optionally other topics.

section.title: Use Cases
section.t: An IOAM profile should define the use case(s) for using the profile. The use case may describe deployment scenarios or specific applications that make use of IOAM data. The use case should typically define the required functionality from IOAM. For example, an IOAM profile may be defined such that it requires transit delay monitoring, but does not require path tracing. These requirements then affect which IOAM data fields are used in the profile.

section.title: Namespace-ID
section.t: IOAM namespaces are defined in Section 4.1 of . An IOAM profile can be bound to a specific Namespace-ID value or to a set of Namespace-ID values. Thus, a profile specification may request IANA to allocate one or more Namespace-ID values. Note that a profile may also be defined without being bound to a specific Namesampe-ID, in which case the profile specification may not include the current section.

section.title: IOAM Options
section.t: IOAM information may be represented in one of four possible IOAM options: Pre-allocated Trace Option, Incremental Trace Option, Proof Of Transit (POT) Option, and Edge-to-Edge Option. An IOAM profile may specify a subset of allowed options. A profile may define some options as mandatory in the current profile, or some options as forbidden in the current profile.

For each IOAM option, a profile specification may limit the scope of the profile to certain features. For example, a profile may be defined to use the Incremental Trace Option such that only specific data types are used in the profile, while others are not.

section.title: IOAM Option Header Field Values
section.t: An IOAM profile may define specific values or specific value range for some of the fields in the IOAM option headers. For example, a profile may define a specific value that is allowed to be used in the Flags field of the trace option header.

section.title: Opaque State Snapshot
section.t: The Opaque State Snapshot, as defined in , is a variable length field that may be used in IOAM trace options. The Opaque State Snapshot is defined in a flexible Type/Length/Value manner. An IOAM profile may define a specific format for the Opaque State Snapshot including for example a specific length and a specific interpretation of the opaque data.

section.title: Timestamp Format
section.t: A profile may specify a specific timestamp format to be used in IOAM data fields.

section.title: Profile Coexistence
section.t: An IOAM node may be configured to operate in one or more IOAM profiles. If more than one profile is enabled, there should be a way for IOAM nodes to distinguish between packets that use different IOAM profiles, e.g., using the Namespace-ID. Therefore, it is recommended that a profile specification includes a definition of how to distinguish between packets from different profiles.

section.title: Validity
section.t: When an IOAM transit node or an IOAM decapsulating node receives a packet with one or more IOAM options, it needs to detect which profile the packet is bound to. The node then needs to perform validity checks including verifying that the packet belongs to one of the profiles that is supported and enabled in the current node, and that all the IOAM options in the current packet conform to the profile specification.

An IOAM transit/decapsulating node that receives a packet with IOAM options that do not pass the validity check can either forward/decapsulate the packet without IOAM processing, or it can process the packet as a conventional IOAM-enabled packet, if it is able to do so and if the network policy allows this behavior.

section.title: IANA Considerations
section.t: This document does not include any requests from IANA.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: The security considerations of IOAM in general are discussed in . This document presents the concept of IOAM profiles; since an IOAM profile is a specific use case of IOAM, any security threat that is relevant to the profile is also relevant to the full-blown IOAM. Therefore, the current document does not present any new security considerations beyond . Moreover, in some cases a profile may limit the set of features of IOAM in a way that reduces the set of potential threats compared a full implementation of IOAM.
